etymology.description: 飠(飠) (shí, "eat") + phonetic: 豚(豚) (tún, "piglet") = round food -> swallow
etymology.interpretation: The character 饨(飩) (tún, "swallow; round food") combines the semantic component 飠(飠) (shí, "eat") with the phonetic component 豚(豚) (tún, "piglet"), suggesting the concept of a round edible item, analogous to how piglets round out when well-fed.
etymology.simplification: Simplified from 飩(飩) by omitting the top component of the radical on the right side, maintaining the sound and meaning.

examples.chinese: 他用汤做饨(他用湯做飩)，味道很好(味道很好)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yòng tāng zuò tún, wèidào hěn hǎo.
examples.english: He makes wontons with soup, and they taste very good.
